meanings.definition: Focused on words or language as the central aspect of thought or culture.
meanings.sent1: The logocentric professor always emphasized the importance of vocabulary in his lectures.
meanings.sent2: She had a logocentric approach to literature, always analyzing the language used by the authors.
meanings.sent3: The logocentric parrot impressed everyone with its ability to mimic complex phrases.
meanings.sent4: His logocentric mind saw the world as a book waiting to be read and understood.
meanings.sent5: The logocentric nature of poetry allows us to explore the depths of human emotion through words.

meanings.definition: Placing excessive importance on words or language.
meanings.sent1: Her logocentric behavior made her focus more on the wording of the email than its content.
meanings.sent2: The logocentric politician was known for his lengthy speeches filled with grandiose language.
meanings.sent3: The logocentric toddler threw a tantrum when his favorite book was misplaced.
meanings.sent4: His logocentric obsession with eloquent speech often overshadowed the actual message he wanted to convey.
meanings.sent5: The logocentric marketing campaign relied heavily on catchy slogans and wordplay to attract customers.

meanings.definition: Centered around the idea that language is the primary means of communication and understanding.
meanings.sent1: The logocentric approach to teaching focused on improving students' language skills above all else.
meanings.sent2: In their logocentric society, verbal communication was considered the most powerful form of expression.
meanings.sent3: The logocentric family had a tradition of passing down stories through generations.
meanings.sent4: Her logocentric worldview shaped her belief that words held the key to unlocking knowledge and connection.
meanings.sent5: The logocentric culture celebrated linguistic diversity and the richness of expression through words.
